docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Lessons of Heart Disease, Learned and Ignored'' (''Six Killers'' series, front page, April 8): You are quite right to highlight the many missed opportunities to prevent heart attacks and save lives by early recognition of heart disease symptoms and consistent, timely use of the best available medications and technologies. But early recognition of heart attack is a sadly limited approach to heart disease prevention. We have long known that populations with comparable genetic susceptibilities, living in different environments, experience dramatically varying rates of heart disease. Most experts concur that routine application of what we already know about healthful lifestyle could reduce heart disease rates in the United States by 80 percent.

headline.main: Many Ways to Fight Heart Disease

docs.abstract: Six letters comment on Apr 8 article about heart disease; Dr David L Katz, director of Prevention Research Center at Yale University School of Medicine, praises focus of article but says early recognition of heart attack is limited approach to disease prevention; Stephen Jones and Andrew Zwarun share their experiences of dealing with medical community while in throes of chest pains; Alice H Lichtenstein, professor of nutrition science and policy at Tufts University, argues that lifestyle modification in high-risk individual is often not enough to lower risk; Michael Scheinberg says people may not go to emergency room when they experience symptoms because of cost; Dr Marta Meyers calls for more access to emergency room treatment; drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Lessons of Heart Disease, Learned and Ignored'' (''Six Killers'' series, front page, April 8):     You are quite right to highlight the many missed opportunities to prevent heart attacks and save lives by early recognition of...

docs.lead_paragraph: A large proportion of breast surgeons never refer their patients to a plastic surgeon for reconstruction, a new study reports. Researchers surveyed 365 surgeons with 1,844 patients in Detroit and Los Angeles in 2002. Only 24 percent of surgeons referred more than three-quarters of their patients for plastic surgery, and 44 percent referred fewer than one-quarter.

headline.main: Few Breast Surgeons Steer Patients to Reconstruction

docs.abstract: Dr Amy K Alderman of University of Michigan leads study that finds only 24 percentage of breast surgeons refer patients to plastic surgeon for reconstruction; research, which is published in journal Cancer, suggests that surgeons do better job explaining all available options to patients who have had breast surgery; drawing (M)

headline.main: How to Fix the Income Gap (4 Letters)
headline.print_headline: How to Fix The Income Gap

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You are right to critique the disturbing pattern of growing income inequality in the United States (''It Didn't End Well Last Time,'' editorial, April 4).

headline.main: How to Fix The Income Gap

docs.abstract: Four letters comment on April 4 editorial on growing income inequality in US; Sen Bernie Sanders of Vermont says hundreds of billions in tax breaks for wealthy should be rescinded and money used to address long-neglected problem of children and working families; James A Parrott holds New York State should begin vigorous effort to stem abuse of private workers being illegally misclassified as independent contractors; Harold Jacobs says distribution of wealth and income is more unequal in US than in any other advanced industrial country; Michael Rodriguez says it is not true that middle-class and poor Americans use government services more than the affluent
